learning_outcomes.description: Understand the basic principles of field theory, and how fields are used in various areas of physics.
Apply mathematical methods of field theory to the quantitative solution of problems.
Understand the role of classical field theory in real-world problems.
Investigate classical fields experimentally, applying laboratory skills and error analysis to test theoretical predictions.
Engage in scientific and technical communication about classical field theory.

assessments.task_description:
To get the most out of each workshop, you will need to prepare beforehand by completing a prescribed reading (approximately 30-60 minutes). Each quiz will generally consist of a short answer question related to the reading material. A mark of 1 is allocated for each quiz where the student successfully demonstrates that they have engaged with the reading.

Grades (on a 1-7 scale) are awarded as per the following:

  • 7: Successful completion of at least 10 quizzes
  • 6: Successful completion of at least 9 quizzes
  • 5: Successful completion of at least 8 quizzes
  • 4: Successful completion of at least 6 quizzes
  • 3: Successful completion of at least 4 quizzes
  • 2: Successful completion of at least 2 quizzes
  • 1: Successful completion of fewer than 2 quizzes


Note that you need only 10 of the 12 reading quizzes to be successfully completed in order to get the full 5%.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The quiz must be submitted electronically via Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.due_date: 5 pm, 2 weeks after completing the second short experiment (see lab schedule)
assessments.task_description: Each student will be allocated into two short experiments. The experiments will be conducted on-campus. You will submit one short laboratory report for either of the two short experiments (your choice of experiment). Teaching staff will check your lab notebook as you are doing the experiment and you will be required to submit a copy as an appendix to your report. The report is limited to 4 pages (excluding a cover page and appendices). Students may discuss a draft report with staff before submission but reports must be your own work. Always cite material and concepts correctly in your submission. We prefer that such material is expressed in your own words rather than quoted directly from the source. Staff reserve the right to use Turnitin software to check the originality of all submitted material. Generative AI use is permitted but its usage must be described in an appendix.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Reports must be submitted electronically via the University's Blackboard system. Submissions must be in portable document format (i.e. a pdf file).
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 1 grade for each 24 hour period from time submission is due will apply for up to 7 days. After 7 days you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date: 5 pm, 2 weeks after completing the experiment (see lab schedule)
assessments.task_description: Each student will be allocated one long experiment. The experiment will be conducted on-campus. You will submit a laboratory report for the experiment. Teaching staff will check your lab notebook as you are doing the experiment and you will be required to submit a copy as an appendix to your report. The report is limited to 6 pages (excluding a cover page and appendices). Students may discuss a draft report with staff before submission but reports must be your own work. Always cite material and concepts correctly in your submission. We prefer that such material is expressed in your own words rather than quoted directly from the source. Staff reserve the right to use Turnitin software to check the originality of all submitted material. Generative AI use is permitted but its usage must be described in an appendix.

assessments.task_description: Students will have an in-semester exam during the semester, scheduled for 6th May 2026, 5 pm (exam location to be advised on Blackboard). This will consist of two parts: the first covering module 1 and the second covering module 2. The exam will involve short answer and problem-solving questions - ensure that your answers include clear physics reasoning. Solutions consisting of only equations and numbers without explanations will be awarded a grade no higher than 4.

assessments.task_description:
The final examination in this course will be held during the end-of-semester examination period. It will be an in-person exam held on campus.

The exam will consist of two parts - the first part will cover module 3 while the second part will consist of advanced questions for all three modules. Each part will involve short answer and problem-solving questions - ensure that your answers include clear physics reasoning. Solutions consisting of only equations and numbers without explanations will be awarded a grade no higher than 4.

learning_activities.topic:
Laboratory

The laboratory activities will help you to develop your skills at physical concepts, data analysis, and communicating results.

An introductory laboratory session will be conducted in Weeks 1 and 2, and students must complete a linear regression exercise before commencing later laboratory experiments.

Students will then be scheduled to two 1-week (short) experiments and one 2-week (long) experiment during the semester. See Blackboard for further details of scheduling.

Opportunities for "catch-up" experiments will be available near the end of semester.
